theorem.p: A subset U\subseteq\mb R is open if and only if there exists a collection of open intervals \mc U such that U=\bigcup\mc U.

proposition.p: Let x\in\mb R and S\subseteq\mb R. The point x is a limit point of the set S if and only if for every open set U containing x, there is a point y\in S such that x\not=y and y\in U.

theorem.p: The open subsets of \mb R satisfy the following properties.

ol.li: \emptyset and \mb R are open sets.
If \mc U is a collection of open sets, then \bigcup\mc U is also an open set.
If U,V are open sets, then U\cap V is an open set.

definition.p: Let X be a set, and let \mc T\subseteq \mc P(X) satisfy the following properties.

ol.li: \emptyset,X\in\mc T.
If \mc U\subseteq\mc T, then \bigcup\mc U\in\mc T.
If U,V\in\mc T, then U\cap V\in\mc T.

definition.p: Then \mc T is called a topology on X, the pair \tuple{X,\mc T} is called a topological space, and elements U\in\mc T are called open sets of the space. (Usually \tuple{X,\mc T} is abbreviated to just X when the topology is known from context.)
Let \mc T\subseteq\mc P(\mb R) be the collection of open subsets of \mb R defined by . Then by , \mc T is a valid topology for \mb R called the Euclidean topology.

theorem.p: Let X be any set. Then the following sets are topologies on X.

ol.li: \mc T=\mc P(X) is called the discrete topology.
\mc T=\{\emptyset,X\} is called the indiscrete topology.

proposition.p: Let \mc T be a topology, and let \mc U\subseteq\mc T be finite. Then \bigcap\mc U\in\mc T.
Let \mc T be the Euclidean topology. There exists a collection \mc U=\{U_n:n\in\mb N\} such that \bigcap\mc U\not\in\mc T.

definition.p: Let \tuple{X,\mc T} be a topological space and let x\in X. The set N\subseteq X is called a neighborhood of x if and only if there exists an open set U\in\mc T such that x\in U\subseteq N.

proposition.p: A subset U of a topological space X is open if and only if U is a neighborhood of every point it contains.

definition.p: The following are known as separation axioms for a topological space \tuple{X,\mc T}.

\mc T is said to be T_0 if and only if for all points x,y\in X such that x

\mc T is said to be T_1 if and only if for all points x,y\in X such that x\not=y, there exists a neighborhood U of x such that y\not\in U.
\mc T is said to be T_2 (also known as Hausdorff) if and only if for all points x,y\in X such that x\not=y, there exist neighborhoods U,V of x,y (respectively) such that U\cap V=\emptyset.

theorem.p: Let X be a finite topological space. Then X is T_1 if and only if X has the discrete topology.

proposition.p: The Euclidean real line is a non-discrete Hausdorff topological space.

definition.p: Let S\subseteq X be a subset of a topological space. The point x is a limit point of the set S if and only if for every neighborhood of U of x, there is a point y\in S such that x\not=y and y\in U.

proposition.p: The point x\in\mb R is a limit point of S\subseteq \mb R according to if and only if it is a limit point according to (where \mb R is assumed to have the Euclidean topology).

definition.p: Let S\subseteq X be a subset of a topological space. Then S' is the set of all limit points of S, called the derived set of S.
Let S\subseteq X be a subset of a topological space. Then \cl S=S\cup S' is called the closure of S.

definition.p: Let H\subseteq X be a subset of a topological space. Then H is called closed if and only if H=\cl S.

theorem.p: Let H\subseteq X be a subset of a topological space. Then H is closed if and only if there exists an open set U such that H=X\setminus U.

proposition.p: The closed subsets of a topological space X satisfy the following properties.

ol.li: \emptyset and X are closed sets.
If \mc H is a collection of closed sets, then \bigcap\mc H is also a closed set.
If H,L are closed sets, then H\cup L is a closed set.

theorem.p: A topological space X is T_1 if and only if every finite subset of X is closed.

definition.p: Let S\subseteq X be a subset of a topological space. The point x is a boundary point of the set S if and only if for every neighborhood of U of x, both S\cap U and S\setminus U are non-empty.
Let \bd S collect all the boundary points of S.
Let S\subseteq X be a subset of a topological space. The point x is a interior point of the set S if and only if there exists a neighborhood U of x such that x\in U\subseteq S.
Let \int S collect all the interior points of S.

proposition.p: Let U\subseteq X be a subset of a topological space. Then U is open if and only if U=\int U.

definition.p: Let S\subseteq X be a subset of a topological space. The point x is a exterior point of the set S if and only if there exists a neighborhood U of x such that x\in U\subseteq X\setminus S.
Let \ext S collect all the exterior points of S.
A partition of a set X is a collection \mc P such that X=\bigcup\mc P and A\cap B=\emptyset for all A,B\in\mc P where A\not=B.

proposition.p: Let S\subseteq X be a subset of a topological space. Then \setList{\int S,\bd S,\ext S} is a partition of X.
Let S\subseteq X be a subset of a topological space. Then \cl S=\int S\cup\bd S=S\cup\bd S.

definition.p: A subset D\subseteq X of a topological space is called dense if and only if \cl D=X.

example.p: Determine which of these are dense subsets of \mb R.

theorem.p: A subset D of a topological space is dense if and only if every open set of the space contains a point of D.

definition.p: Let Y\subseteq X for a topological space \tuple{X,\mc T}. Then the subspace topology for Y is given by \mc T_Y=\setBuilder{U\cap Y}{U\in\mc T}.

proposition.p: The subspace topology is a valid topology.

definition.p: Let \tuple{X,\mc T} be a topological space. A subset \mc B\subseteq\mc T is called a basis for the topology if for every x\in X and neighborhood U of x, there exists B\in\mc B such that x\in B\subseteq U.

proposition.p: \mc B=\setBuilder{(a,b)}{a,b\in\mb R} is a basis for the Euclidean topology.

theorem.p: Let \mc B\subseteq\mc P(X) satisfy the following properties:

ol.li: For all x\in X, there exists B\in\mc B such that x\in B.
If x\in A\in\mc B and x\in B\in\mc B, there exists C\in\mc B such that x\in C\subseteq A\cap B.

theorem.p: Then \mc T=\setBuilder{\bigcup\mc U}{\mc U\subseteq\mc B} is a topology, and \mc B is a basis for that topology. We call this the topology generated by the basis.

proposition.p: \mc B=\setBuilder{[a,b)}{a,b\in\mb R} is a basis for a topology different from the Euclidean topology, called the Sorgenfrey topology.

definition.p: The following are also known as separation axioms for a topological space \tuple{X,\mc T}.

ol.li: \mc T is said to be regular if and only if for all points x\in X and closed subsets H\subseteq X such that x\not\in H, there exist open sets U,V\in\mc T such that x\in U,H\subseteq V,U\cap V=\emptyset.
\mc T is said to be T_3 if and only if it is both regular and T_1
\mc T is said to be normal if and only if for all closed subsets H,L\subseteq X such that H\cap L=\emptyset, there exist open sets U,V\in\mc T such that H\subseteq U,L\subseteq V,U\cap V=\emptyset.
\mc T is said to be T_4 if and only if it is both normal and T_1

theorem.p: The real line \mb R equipped with the Euclidean topology is T_4.

example.p: Find or create an example of a topological space that is:

ol.li: T_2 but not regular.
T_3 but not T_4
Regular but not T_3.
Normal but not T_4.
Regular but not normal.
Normal but not regular.

theorem.p: A topological space is T_3 if and only if it is regular and T_0.
